ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned many skills such as analysis of ancient primary sources while learning about the historical context of the Hebrew Bible.
Historical analysis particularly with an eye for analysis primary texts; knowledge of the fascinating history of the ancient near East and the Hebrew peoples role within it.

This class was one of the best I have taken during my time at Yale. I learned how to conduct an effective comparative analysis of texts side by side, how to analyze primary source biblical texts, and how to engage critically with primary source material. I was fascinated to learn how the bible existed in its ancient near eastern setting and how Assyrian and Mesopotamian texts influence biblical texts.
Great perspective on the Bible and its impact on the world.
I gained an insight into the study of the Hebrew Bible in its Ancient Near Eastern context, along with comparative methods for the study of various cultures of the Ancient Near East.

A more deep understanding of Assyrian and Babylonian histories while comparing them to the history of the Kingdoms of Israel and Judea. There is an emphasis in this class on archaeology due to the professor's background.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The experiential learning aspects of this course were memorable and something that I personally looked forward to. It was so cool to see the Gilgamesh tablet in Sterling Memorial Library and to handle some of those ancient artifacts. I also enjoyed the class presentations that we all did on one text. I appreciated how these presentations were more informal and laid back- they made me feel comfortable familiarizing myself with a text that interested me and because of their informal nature I was able to focus more on understanding the content I was analyzing rather than on just trying to go above and beyond to get a good grade. The course overall challenged me to look beyond my personal beliefs and analyze the bible in a historical context. I learned so much. The balance of assignments was also great. Again, the nature and the focus on reading as part of our assignments made me more motivated to actually understand and sit with the texts we were studying. I appreciated how we only had two papers and didn't have to do unnecessary external work like post on discussion forums on Canvas.

This may seem basic, but I wish we spent the first class or two going over dates and how things are being dated (ex: how the BC system of dating works). There were times when I got confused with the dates presented in materials and during class lectures.
More discussion could be fun, but overall the lecture component and student presentations worked well! The class was organized in a way that made sense.

This course needs work in its branding. It isn't really a seminar. It is more of a lecture, with powerpoints and a sprinkling of student comments. I also criticize this course because its framework was unchanging. That is beneficial in some ways but more detrimental in my point of view. We came into every lecture with two stories, one from the Torah and one from an ancient near eastern source. Good. I like this symmetry. But... the professor's take on every single comparison was the exact same: The Torah gets most elements from Babylonian/Assyrian sources and because it does this what does it say about others. Rather than letting the students figure out these connections themselves, the professor kind of rams this narrative down their throats.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, the professor is very passionate, and the subject matter is incredibly interesting.
Yes, provided they have a modicum of interest in either the Bible of the ancient near East.

Yes- absolutely. This class was essential to learn how to analyze primary source materials and to conduct a comparative analysis of these texts. This class challenged me and expanded my knowledge of both Biblical texts and Assyriology. I wish I had taken it earlier!
Yes, it provides a solid introduction to ANE and Biblical Studies, and provides historical context for one of the most important texts in world history.
No simply because it is branded incorrectly (see above) and because there is little room for student interpretation.

extras.title: NELC 115 01/NELC 515 01 - Bible in Ancient Near East
